awd_titl_txt: Reconfigurable Liquid-Metal RF Circuits and Antennas Using Electrical Actuation
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed research will investigate electrically controlled actuation of liquid metals, helping to create the foundation for the design of reconfigurable devices and circuits that use liquid metals. Reconfigurable electronics have the unique ability to change their operational parameters, allowing them to adapt to specific tasks or environments. The amorphous nature of liquid metal allows for the creation of dynamic conductors whose shape and position can be altered to adapt to changing environments or operating parameters. Imagine, for example, a mobile electronic device that can reconfigure its communication system to provide the highest efficiency, and thus the longest battery life, in a variety of environments. This research has the potential to impact the electronics and telecommunication industries, and can enable more effective and efficient use of the wireless frequency spectrum. In addition, the research into the actuation methods has applications to fields outside of reconfigurable electronics, including microfluidics and lab- on-chip systems. This project will also support the inclusion of underrepresented Native Hawaiian students, will involve undergraduate students in the proposed research, and will support outreach to K-12 students.


We will investigate low-voltage electrically controlled actuation methods for the actuation of liquid metals, and tailor these methods to applications in reconfigurable radio-frequency (RF) circuits. The actuation methods that will be focused on include a novel hybrid form of electrocapillary and electrochemical actuation, electrical capillary actuation coupled with quantized shapes of liquid metal, and continuous electrowetting. Reconfigurable circuits using each type of actuation method will be demonstrated: liquid-metal antennas that can shapeshift to change their operating characteristics, and microwave-frequency switches that have the potential for low insertion loss, high isolation, and high reliability. The proposed research will also address an important issue in liquid-metal devices: loss at microwave frequencies due to the use of aqueous electrolytes. Device architectures will be developed that are agnostic to this effect, take advantage of the loss, or minimize the loss by removing or displacing the electrolyte. The adaptation of each proposed liquid-metal actuation method to the unique constraints and requirements of reconfigurable circuits is novel. The actuation methods will be showcased by creating new types of reconfigurable circuits operating at microwave frequencies. The resulting devices will have performance characteristics that are unique or that exceed the current state-of-the-art in reconfigurable electronics. Thus, this research will advance the field of liquid-metal circuits, and create new technologies for realizing reconfigurable RF circuits. New knowledge of liquid-metal actuation will be generated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Next-generation wireless communication systems can be made more efficient, adaptable, and reliable - imagine mobile phones that use less power throughout the day while maintaining a strong signal. This project developed technology that can help to realize this vision: liquid metals for reconfigurable electronics. We focused on gallium alloys, which are liquid at room temperature but much less toxic than mercury. Using techniques developed by our research team, we are able to use electrical signals to transport and change the shape of these liquid metals.

This project enabled some foundational work towards using liquid metals for reconfigurable circuits. We demonstrated reversible physical and electrical connections between separate volumes of liquid metals, which is helpful for interfacing liquid metals with other circuit elements. The electrical actuation of liquid metal relies on an electrolyte of sodium hydroxide, which was characterized for use in microwave circuits and systems. We showed that electrical actuation can move liquid-metal droplets over a 2D area, and in microchannels with widths as small as 75 ?m. We also demonstrated that liquid metal can be extrusion printed with microscale resolution.

This project built upon our foundational work and showcased liquid-metal functionality in a variety of useful applications. We demonstrated tunable inductors and capacitors that used liquid metal. The results of the study on the properties of sodium hydroxide were used to accurately model the measured performance of a liquid-metal radio-frequency switch. We also showed that electrically actuated liquid metal can function as a tunable unit cell for reconfigurable intelligent surfaces. Additionally, we showed that liquid-metal droplets can help to cool localized hot spots, which could help with the thermal management of high-power circuits. The research results from this project were disseminated in three journal papers, seven conference papers, and one thesis paper. An additional journal paper has been submitted.

This project also closely integrated research and education. The PI and Co-PI co-advised a Liquid-Metal Electronics Vertically Integrated Project (VIP) team. This team consisted of graduate students and undergraduate students of various levels (freshman to senior), as well as high school students, all working together on research topics related to this project. Three of the undergraduate students involved in this project were awarded NSF Graduate Research Fellowships who are currently working toward their doctorate degrees. The PI and Co-PI also team-taught an integrated graduate/undergraduate course on liquid-metal reconfigurable microwave/millimeter-wave circuits and systems, with a focus on reconfigurable intelligent surfaces.
